post.title: Summer 2022: Hot and Getting Hotter
post.content:encoded:
Above average temperatures are the new abnormal in the 21st century

If the last few summers have felt hotter than usual, you are not wrong and you are probably not alone.

NOAA keeps data on average monthly temperatures for the United States (lower 48 states) going back to 1895, the warming trend is clearly in the numbers.

Below is a data visualization I made showing the average monthly temperatures during the summer months of June to September, for each year between 1895 and 2022. The five hottest years on record for each month are marked with the magenta dots, and the five coldest are the blue dots. The average temperature for each month from the 127 years of data is marked by the purple dashed line.

Note that almost all of the magenta dots fall either in the last two decades, or during the dust bowl years of the 1930s. Put another way: in the last two decades, above average temperatures have become the norm.

The average U.S. temperature for all four months in 2022 was 72.45 F, making it the hottest summer on record by that metric.

For what it’s worth, NOAA uses other metrics to define the summer period. The meteorological summer is June, July, and August; and 2022 was the third hottest summer on record by that definition. There is also the astronomical summer, which is marked by the June 21/22 solstice and September 21/22 equinox. No word yet on where 2022 ranked by that definition, but probably pretty high given the data above.
